Stardew Valley is a farming RPG that is fun in concept, but in my experience unfortunately not in actual gameplay.

This is one of the instances where I wish I could give a mixed review, however as my experience has been more negative than positive, this will have to do.

The game is fun for the first couple of hours, but as a game mainly consisting of routine, it gets rather repetitive as time goes on. You wake up, are able to do the same three things every single day before the day is over, and then it just starts all over again.

This leads me to the point of the time management and day cycles being just short of horrible. As the days are over too quickly to get much done, the days end up being foo fast paced while the overall progress is too slow paced. It takes too long to achieve anything at all, and it‚Äôs therefore too much of a grind for me.

Having to watch the stamina bar, health bar and the time at almost all times turns a game mainly advertised as cozy into quite the stressful experience.

Another issue I personally have within the game are the eye straining graphics & coloring. I‚Äôm aware that the game has its own stylistic elements, however I can‚Äôt play the game for more than roughly two hours at a time before the headache sets in.

A lot of these issues can be fixed through the use of mods, however I‚Äôm not a fan of having to use mods in order to deem a game as playable while ignoring the flawed aspects of the game.

I can sort of understand how Stardew Valley might be fun and fulfilling to some, especially if they have a lot of time on their hands, but for me, the game is just too stressful and unrewarding to actually have fun.

The NPCs and the concept of the dating sim were what had initially awakened my interest in the game, and as far as the NPCs‚Äô designs go, I can‚Äôt complain. However, all of them have fairly limited dialogue and interaction options. This gets noticeable after just a quite short time of playing and only adds onto the repetitive aspect of the game.

I might pick the game up again in the future in order to try to 100% complete a farm, but that would probably take a while as I would just lose motivation over and over again.

For the price, I feel it‚Äôs worth to give Stardew Valley a try and see whether the game is suitable for you or not, however in my case, this game ended up not being as fun as advertised.

I really wanted to enjoy this game, and I do enjoy some similar games (Graveyard Keeper, for instance). However, this has some fatal flaws that just suck the fun right out of it. Most importantly, it's intensely boring.

1) The intro music and sound: It's not huge, but right off the bat this thing just BLASTS the music and sound effects at full volume and refuses to provide any real settings until you've completed the introduction (2 or 3 minutes straight). Muted my computer instead of listening to that nonsense. The menu is full volume every time you start the game. (You can mute the music side of it, to be clear).

2) The controls: Clunky doesn't even begin to describe this thing. Targeting your actions is incredibly imprecise, your movements are blocked by all sorts of things (small rocks, dandelions, random weeds), and everything is done via the same action key.

3) The energy bar: Good lord, why is this a thing? You use enormous amounts of energy just watering the garden or fishing. There's no argument of realism to be made, since you're fighting monsters in a cave and growing vegetables in a week. It's a cheesy mechanism to make the game take longer and force you to do fewer things in a given day.

4) The NPCs: There's no point in talking to any of them. I realize that you can build relationships with them and get additional interactions, but why would I want to when they only have one line that they repeat. The hobo who lives north of town is the only guy who I ran into who was interesting in the slightest.

The only part of the game I found even remotely entertaining was translating the message at the Community Center, and literally 3 minutes after I finished doing that the game just handed me the translation. That's right, I spent half an hour transcribing the fictional symbols on the tablet into Latin letters and figuring out the substitution cipher that was used rather than plant more parsnips, catch another fish, or fight flies in the mine for the 39th floor in a row. I wasn't able to translate the tombstone, but I didn't put much effort into that, so it may be possible.

Just not into this kind of game. love farming, mining, exploration, and quests but not the limited to time, NPCs on schedules, story/dialogue, and not open-world stuff. Did this purely to see if steam would not recommend stardew-like games to me.

It's unfortunate this game has been as successful as it has. Itself is a pale and malnourished imitation of its betters, now spawning its own inbred and equally deficient, if not worse, imitators. It's naive to assume a one man dev can replicate the quality and breadth of a studio made game like Story of Seasons or Rune Factory, but the developer squandered the agility and freedom he had when you step back and assess the game systems.

One of the biggest issues, one that I think exemplifies everything wrong with Stardew Valley, is that item quality exists in a kind of vacuum which creates a dominoes effect of wasting your time. There's no real reason to aim for top quality in anything. Quality is not additive. You will not be making high sell price cooked dishes out of top quality produce. The cooked dish will always be the same price regardless of what you use. Why bother keeping sheep at all when the quality of wool only determines a chance you might weave more than one piece of single-quality fabric? Why keep chickens, cows, etc, for similar reasons? The lack of any kind of consistency in this aspect has spawned several bandaids to adding back stripped quality, like the end game spice and aging casks, but it's just another waste of time. This is on top of the fact there are no maker queues, so if you're wondering why you have to baby your machines like you're trapped playing an abusive mobile game in these contemporary farming sims now, this is patient zero for that, apparently. Thanks, I guess.

While waking up for the umpteenth morning to dutifully check your crab pots for no real reason, you will find yourself in a village that is one heart event away from experiencing its own fentanyl crisis. Everyone is an alcoholic or alcoholic adjacent, orphaned or widowed, impoverished and struggling, abused, traumatized, suicidal, or just plain mentally ill. There's this immense tonal chasm between the writing, rural folk trapped by a lack of opportunities and an abundance of neuroses, and the world itself, one filled with talking fish and magic and monsters, and never do the two ever meet. I joked while playing this that it's a secret ancap game because there's no reason to pick nature over jojamart. In fact, the game punishes characters for your supposedly good and holistic deeds. And for what? A nice little building that nobody ever goes into and nothing inside is usable? Ironically, or perhaps on purpose, in a game filled with alcoholics, one of the best ways to make money is wine. It's accidentally misanthropic if nothing else.

If you played Pioneers of Olive Town and want to understand how such a disastrous thing could be made, or if you've just replayed Trio of Towns or RF4 too many times at this point, Stardew Valley is an interesting specimen to study for a few dozen hours (with mods, ideally.) It's a slow motion car crash, the likes of which we are still feeling the damage from and likely will continue to do so for many years to come. What an accomplishment.

I've enjoyed Stardew Valley as something that has potential to engage with, there are a variety of characters that I wanted to get to know and it‚Äôs cute even if I find its personality to be mostly flat. It‚Äôs opening monologue from your passing grandfather, and his get-out-of-corporate-jail-free-card, the rundown farm he gives you, is an invitation to vanish from the soul-sucking life under capitalism we are all desperately searching for. It pokes at the nerve of that fantasy in a gentle and hopeful way. That being said, from my admittedly short, under 20 hour playthrough, my conclusion is that this game is more of a career change than any sort of escape, and your ‚Äúidyllic small-business-owner life‚Äù does a lot of things with roughly the same level of mediocrity and lethargy as any busy-work office-job can offer.

This may feel like nitpicking but I'd like to start with the observation that the movement is very game-y. Robotically responsive, no kinetic energy. This is pretty indicative, I think, of most of my issues with the game, nothing really feels good to actually perform. It‚Äôs floaty, you don‚Äôt develop any sort of kinetic connection to the place or work while playing, (maybe except the fishing minigame) its tasks are time-consuming, menial, and everything needs to be pried out of its respective shell to be experienced. You hardly interact with anything and really anyone in Stardew Valley unless it's to click-extract some resource, and it doesn‚Äôt even feel good to do it.

Some villager encounters were pleasant enough but they usually began with me barging into their rooms. (Abigail, Elliot and Leah for example.) Abigail thought it weird for a moment that I just showed up unannounced into her private space the first time but because this was a friendship cutscene the game had already given me the consent needed to enter these people's rooms without any emotional consequence. A disconnected emotional experience, between what is supposed to be a developing relationship between yourself and an in-game neighbor, and the game needing to hit each plot-point in its episodic small-town tv-drama way. It's stilted and feels so unearned even if the moments‚Äô emotional peaks were low stakes and mostly just pleasant. The scenes themselves make sense emotionally but only if you ignore this kind of staging, and I just can‚Äôt get past that. This weird dissonance was felt throughout my whole experience, again, it just felt like I was being catered to. In a game about developing a farm by yourself, fighting monsters in a cave by yourself, gathering resources and redeveloping a town by yourself, the in-person cutscenes with townsfolk felt like some of the loneliest parts of the game.

The farm development portion of this game also felt lacking to me. Your main goal is inevitably towards automation since you do all the work alone. Which is an understandable conclusion, given the potential amount of work there will become as you expand your facilities and output. It just makes Stardew Valley into a game about always making a bigger number: more crops, more farm animals, more money, etc. Purely preference of course, but the more I play games, the less I‚Äôm compelled by that notion alone.

All that said, I enjoyed this game for a while, as something small to do everyday for about two weeks, give or take. I would get up in the morning, make a cup of coffee and play 3 in-game days before moving on with my own day. This is a game of rituals and incorporating Stardew Valley into one of my own was probably the most meaningful connection I made with the game. It was at times pleasant and it's not completely devoid of character. My time in Pelican Town lasted as long as it did at the urging of my friends and the small deliberate sessions of play not leaving the game totally mealy-in-my-mouth afterwards. Just long enough not to out-stay its welcome. Until it did. My playthrough is far from complete but this was still a 20-hour experience, and after that long, for its best moments to be turned into a morning routine/chore, is both very fitting for the kind of experience I feel it had fostered up until that point, and is the road sign that points me to the nearest exit out of town.

Stardew Valley is an anagram of WALD VERYSLEAT, an acronym for "WALking behinD VERY SLow pEople when you're in A hurry simulaTor" which perfectly describes this ADHD-driven mess of unfinished amalgamation of ideas.

You move to Pellican Town to work on a farm you inherited from your grandfather. You get to grow crops, tend to farm animals and commune with the townspeople. In the process, you will grow a relationship with NPCs, maybe marry, hone your skills in farming, foraging, fish, eh, fishing?... mining? Comb- wait, combat?

The game will throw everything at you at once: fishing, quests, upgrades, NPC relationships, birthdays, town events. You have limited energy to do daily farm chores and it is never enough. You won't have money to buy crop seeds AND energy items. You're stuck with watering plants ONE BY ONE everyday. Some upgrades are supposed to alleviate that, but they require resources and $ which you still don't have. Some mechanisms are simply missing (mass seeding) whereas others are so endgame (mass fertilizer) that you might as well call them missing.

You walk SLOW. Mining and chopping animations, eating, slide in/out, fade in/out transitions, even the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• load game screen is SLOW-BY-DESIGN. WALD VERYSLEAT. It is INFURIATING. One in-game day is 14m20s IRL, a walk to the mines takes ~43sec. Forgot something? Lol. Anything that makes the game tolerable (larger bags, horse, quality tools and sprinklers) costs $, which requires many hours of watering plants and nothing else. In single player, the game pauses when you're looking your inventory, cutscenes, etc but not in multiplayer. With two players I had (in a way) twice the energy but half of the farm space, twice the cost for upgrading tools and about 30% less time per day.

Artstyle is usually good, but some sprites are obviously from a different project (e.g. Desert Festival). Some NPCs are good, others are cringy charicatures, stereotypes trying hard to feel real. High quality produce converts into regular quality goods (e.g. all grapes produces regular wine, all fish produces regular sashimi), as if the devs forgot about it. Most food is useless as ingredients are better (both price- and energy-wise) than cooking them. You can have children but they remain as toddlers forever. There aren't "multiple playstyles", everything converges to casks+kegs with ancient and/or starfruit.

I don't consider this to be even playable without mods. Achievements work but the hardest one is an unrelated shoot-them-up minigame which is just as enjoyable as rolling until you get 400 on 20d20. It works fine on Linux but I wish it didn't. I cannot overstate this: unless you enjoy WALD VERYSLEAT, this game is TERRIBLE. I do not understand how this has so many positive reviews.

Honestly, I'm not sure why people play this. It's basically about spending hours doing menial tasks and walking around talking to people for slow upgrades. I'm tired of watering my large field of crops every day. I was relieved when I was able to make my first spinkler... until I made one and discovered it has almost no range at all so it's useless, unless I build tons of them which will require too much ressources and waste crop space. If I want a better sprinkler, it won't come until many more hours of this tedium until I have upgraded my farming level a lot more. Well screw it, I'm done.

Just kinda meh. I don't regret picking it up, but it's just not that good. Doesn't do much to improve on the games it was inspired by, they just didn't exist on PC before this game reminded every-developer-forever that you can make money with 'New Guy/Gal in Town' games. With just a single dev, updates are few and far between. Will likely be outdone by other games, if it hasn't been already.

There aren't many ways to modify anything meaningful when starting a file. Selecting the type of farm you have throughout the game is the most meaningful option. You can 'force year one completion', but you need to make sure that you're checking the time-sensitive vendor every time it's available or you're just out of luck for that year.

Days go by too quickly. This is a much bigger problem in multiplayer due to time not stopping in menus or during cutscenes. Kinda ruins the whole 'laid-back' feel I would expect from a game like this. The core loop is very very basic, and nothing really changes even after unlocks. Grow things, sell them. Sometimes you age them for a period of time but really it's just all the same. No crossbreeding, no genetics, no hybrid plants, just plant a seed, water it, and wait. I can understand not wanting to make farming that deep, but I was expecting the depth to show up in cooking recipes or raising animals.

You can fish and raise animals, but again, a lot of the outputs are just things you throw in the box to sell.

Cooking is the biggest disappointment. I expected a lot more from a game like this, but there are really only a handful of useful recipes and everything else is just filler. Most of the best/useful recipes are locked behind leveling-up character relationships. This isn't really a problem... until you realize how bad the other recipes are.

Interactions with villagers are cute, but don't always have depth to them. In my experience it just boiled down to giving a liked item as often as possible to get a recipe as fast as possible. Characters are unique, have schedules ect, but there is no in-game way to track any of it. I don't really focus on this side of games like this, but the lack of QoL around the relationship part of the game is noticeable.

Shops are also not available on certain days, which is just obnoxious. Doubly so when you waste hours running into town only to realize it's a Friday and the blacksmith isn't there.

I'm not a fan of the events because they take up the whole day. You CAN skip them, but it's really not a good idea at least for the first time going through a year. More seem to get added with every major update. I found them to be necessary and didn't like that I couldn't do whatever I had planned to do that day, but I'm probably in the minority.

Some aspects are very RNG heavy in a way that doesn't respect your time. There are a few important rare drops (prismatic shards are the biggest offender) with very low drop rates. If there wasn't a duplication glitch in multiplayer to help mitigate the time-sinks, I probably would have stopped playing.

The combat sucks. Not the focus of the game, but it is important to progression. Everything is basically a sword with faster or slower swing speed. There are also very limited ranged options. There's a wizard in town... but you can't do magic. Need to keep that realism I guess. Turnips grow in four days though.

10 years from now when the dev gets around to improving and expanding on the gameplay I'll probably like it more. Mods probably make the game much more enjoyable, but they aren't through the workshop so I haven't bothered.

Something is just off with this game. I'd say the biggest issue is the need to have a wiki open to play the game because if you don't, the game doesn't respect your time. Didn't know you needed some specific item for a fair? Well there's always next year (which is about 25 hours of real life time).

I want to preface this with the fact I've never been a fan of the sim genre, so keep that in mind.

I actually find the farming gameplay fairly fun. But my overall experience has been meh. A lot of my issues come down to QOL, dialogue, and the general non-farming elements of this game.

It feels like it's trying to do too much and ultimately gives a "jack of all trades, master of none" experience. Every feature except for the standard farming feels mediocre.

Dialogue is painfully dull and only becomes kind of interesting when you become a LOT closer with the townsfolk. This is fine I suppose except you're also supposed to *marry* someone, effectively making sdv a dating sim as well. Except, because of this lack of personality from npcs, none of them really "hook" you or are likeable/interesting enough to keep you pursing them. When you first meet them they're all just kind of meandering around and kind of just say hi to you or are just plain rude. One of them is straight up misogynistic (like around the second and fourth time you talk to him) and the other straight up tells you you're ugly (like the second time you talk to her). Again, I don't mind if npcs dislike you. But why would I try to even befriend someone who tells me I'm ugly or is misogynistic?

And the male npcs have vastly different ways of speaking and beginning dialogue while the female ones really don't except for Haley and the older women. This immediately makes the male npcs more unique and fleshed out than the women ones.

Decay system sucks, which is where if you skip talking with a character for a day or two, their friendship decreases and you have to work to build it back up. There were days where I didn't feel like walking across the map and just wanted to farm in near my house, but no, I HAD to walk to talk to a character so I wouldn't lose progress. All this really turned me off the marriage system and I wouldn't have tried to do if a marriage partner didn't help you around your farm.

I get that all of this this is probably to emulate real life dating, which is a long process of searching and getting to know multiple people until you find "the one," but in a video game with a lot of walking, npcs, and bedtimes, this doesn't translate well.

Other annoyances with the npc system is that apparently there are cutscenes you can trigger, but you have to be at specific places at specific times, but you're never told when or where and there are a few you can PERMAMENTLY miss. These cutscenes help flesh out the world and characters but you probably won't see them unless you have the wiki open 24/7. Also with most npcs when you give them gifts they literally just say the same thing, this isn't bad but for example if you give Sebastion the exact same thing and he loves it, he will always only say, "I love this, how did you know?" it just makes the dialogue feel that much cheaper/less immersive, and would have been nice if he said something like "I love this, thanks for getting me this again." This isn't hard to code at all and feels like an oversight.

When you enter a cutscene, which usually involves entering an area, your character moves around automatically. This is fine of course but when the cutscene ends you're transported immediately back to the entrance of the area, signifying that cutscenes are more like just separate videos that the player watches and not experiences that actually happen in the world/with the characters. Again, not a big deal, but it's multiple, small things like this that build up and break the immersion/vibes.

There's also a lot of cute and interesting things in buildings, but you can't interact or do anything with most of them, to the point I don't even understand why they're there. It'd be interesting if you could go into a store, go to a shelf, and actually buy stuff off of it but you can't.

You can't save without ending your day. It makes the game feel tedious and stressful in early/mid game where you have you really be efficient with your time and make the most out of your day. No clue why it was designed like this. This combined with the fact that most events are one-day only, basically makes the game feel like mini-fomo. This also relates to...

Places closing early REALLY annoyed me at the very beginning of the game, basically forcing me to manage my money and time extremely well just so I could buy the beginner materials. One of my favorites: Stardew Valley

How do I sum up one of my favorite games of all time? One of the first co-ops I played with my girlfriend (now wife), and one that gave us so many good memories that its theme played as our wedding song?

The story is simple: To get away from the hustle and bustle of life in the big city, you move to your late grandfather's farm in Pelican Town, Stardew Valley. However, after many years with no one there, the farm is in disrepair and it's your job to rebuild it into a homestead your old grandpa would be proud of.

At first glance, Stardew Valley looks like the quintessential farming sim, with the story and mechanics modeled after the legendary Harvest Moon. But it is so much more - aside from tending to crops and animals, you can forage, fish, mine, fight monsters, explore, and interact with the citizens of Pelican Town. Eventually, you can visit and explore several exotic locations outside Pelican Town, each with unique puzzles, secrets, and NPCs.

It's truly crazy just how much there is to do in this game, and the best part is, you can do any of these things in any order you want - or none at all. Ultimately, it's up to you to decide what you want to do and how you want the game to progress. The game manages to strike that perfect balance of giving you just enough structure so you're not running around like a headless chicken, but are also not being hand-held the entire time.

The presentation is, quite frankly, delightful. The pixel graphics, character portraits, and soundtrack all work together to build a supremely cozy and relaxing vibe. The writing is surprisingly deep for this type of game, touching on some pretty dark themes without coming off as tasteless.

Of course, not everything is perfect. The constant lack of energy in the early stages, before you have a few tool upgrades under your belt, can be pretty frustrating. The hard cap where your character passes out at 2AM feels like your mom calling you in because it's past your bedtime. And for veteran players like me, who are returning after a major update to check out all the new stuff, it can be a bit of a slog to go through the base game content again in a new playthrough.

But all of these are minor gripes, especially when you consider that almost everything was made by one person. What Eric Barone did here truly boggles the mind.

The real magic of Stardew Valley is that, at least for me, every time I start another playthrough, it feels like coming home. And I can think of no higher praise to give.

On the surface, it seems like an indie version of games like Harvest Moon, where you micromanage a farm, talk to villagers, pursue a love interest, and so on. The fact that the game gives you a clear goal right from the start‚Äîbuilding up your farm well enough to impress your dying Grandpa within two in-game years‚Äîis great motivation. I‚Äôm generally not into games that don‚Äôt have some kind of end goal beyond your personal ambitions. This is an indie game made with a ton of love and care, and it shows in the surprising amount of detail. One thing that really hit for me personally was the 2D Legend of Zelda-style dungeon mode. Farming slimes, leveling up combat abilities, and collecting resources in the mines were easily the most fun parts of the ‚Äúgrinding‚Äù in this game. It made the game stand out from the usual farm sims.

Even the core farming elements‚Äîlike chopping trees, fishing, planting crops, and taking care of your pet‚Äîwere addicting and fun.

"Stardew Valley" is a captivating indie game that blends farming, exploration, and social interaction in a way that feels deeply immersive and rewarding. At its core, the game revolves around inheriting a dilapidated farm and transforming it into something prosperous while building relationships with the quirky townspeople. The appeal lies in its simplicity and freedom, allowing players to choose how they want to spend their time, whether it's farming, fishing, mining, or getting to know the various characters.

The farming mechanics are surprisingly deep, with each season offering different crops and challenges, making each year feel unique. Growing your farm from a small patch of land to a thriving operation is incredibly satisfying, and the game‚Äôs relaxed pace makes it a great way to unwind. However, it‚Äôs not just about growing crops. "Stardew Valley" also encourages you to explore, fish, and mine, each activity adding a different layer of excitement. The mines, for example, offer both treasure and danger, and the thrill of discovering valuable resources or battling monsters keeps the game fresh.

I had heard about Stardew Valley from a lot of friends through the years. I was told that this was a game well worth my time, but it was a title that I allowed to let slip by because I took it for the face value graphics - and I couldn't have been more wrong for doing so. This game is a gem, a masterpiece of an art form lost to time. It's reminiscent of a bygone Nintendo era, bringing me back to this nostalgic feeling I last felt playing on my old Nintendo Game Boy on a forgotten Pok√©mon title - but this game isn't that. It's its own unique thing and that's the beauty behind it.

Your own custom character takes charge of an old farmstead and you yourself bring it back to life alongside the residents of Pelican Town. You farm, you tend the land, you tend to livestock, go fishing, explore spooky caverns, fight creepy creatures, mine, and interact with a lively and dynamic citizenry. You can trade, you can attend town events, and help them out through local job postings. There's just so much you can do in the game and only after almost 20 hours in and I feel like I've only scratched the surface of how amazing this game is.


From the start, I fell in love with the agriculture system. You till the land, you spread your fertilizer/retainer soil, and you sow the seeds, and water. I love that it's not the same seeds year around either, as the mix changes with each season, so you get this unique variety that never really becomes redundant. I'm currently experimenting with changing up what kinds of crops/plants I like to grow and have started crafting artisan items from them and profiting immensely from them. My margins from just selling the raw crops have doubled now that I've started to also create actual items from them.

I also love the dynamic feel of Pelican Town and the unique relationships with all the characters that inhabit it. Everyone has their own unique personality and there's a lovely mechanic with how you interact with them - choosing your own dialogue options - and developing (or hindering) the relationship from there. You can also marry someone you might have an eye on if you develop your relationship with them enough. I also really enjoy the different events that happen through town every month/season. It makes the entire world feel so real and really helps you connect with the Pelican Town community in its entirety. Some of the characters I really like (love Abigail's company, love Robin, don't mind the Mayor), and others I sort of really despise (not a fan of Clint, and Pierre... definitely don't like that guy), but it's all enjoyable with how those relationships develop!

I also love the sense of freedom the game conveys. While the core element of the game remains you owning a farm and choosing what you do with that farm (be it that of growing crops or raising livestock) - but there's also various other forms of income you can choose to do with. I like that you're able to make money off the spoils of your adventures in the mines, or maybe you prefer the fishing dynamics and you make money off of that, or maybe you just love to forage (albeit not as well paying). I just love that the game gives you the freedom to do with that as you please. The freedom to decorate as well - choosing how you want your home and homestead to be set up is very nice!

I also really loved the soundtrack. I hate to keep referring to an Nintendo title, but the main theme in Pelican Town reminds me so much of the Yoshi's Island theme. It's hard enough to acknowledge that it reminds me of Pok√©mon, and now I keep hearing something out of the Super Mario Bros. universe coupled with that! Love it either way because still, it's its own unique thing! It's not either of those titles!


I can't say that I hate anything about this game. I loved just about everything. There are some things I think I'd change, but for a game almost a decade since its release, I'm very very happy with what I've seen and experienced.

I will say, though, I'm not really a fan of the combat mechanic in this game. I find it very limiting that your combat is only limited to the cave explorations, and even that feels horribly redundant exploring those caves. I was expecting a lot more from the Adventurer's Guild - something akin to the Fighter's Guild from , but this felt more akin to slayer tasks from . Exploring those caves feels like just a side effect/necessity of mining for resources and I honestly wish there was more to it.

The day and hour mechanic drives me nuts. Some days I have either too much to do in a day and some days I have too little to do. Specifically, I'm not a fan with how as soon as 2am rolls around, and if I'm not in bed by then, my character plops down asleep and I get mugged or dropped at the expensive doctor in town. Either way, you pay a hefty monetary fine and I just feel like it's a strange penalty mechanic when there should be other ways to stave off that time mechanic - hell, if only 3am was allowed as the limit, it'd save so much time on my end.

This is more of a nitpick on my end, but I wish there was a clearer framework of what opportunities are unlocked as you raise your farming skills and such. Developed by a single developer for more than 4 years, Stardew Valley is a top-down, roleplaying, farming simulation game, and somehow much more.

As you start the game you create your character as you see fit, choose favorite pet and the style of farm (and its name), and you can also customize some game mechanics and multiplayer options.

The initial premise of this game is the inheritance of a farm and after a non-disclosed amount of time working in an office job, your character decides to move to said farm only to find it covered by overgrown weeds. It‚Äôs up to the player to decide what will be the best course of action to take.

Alongside the different crops the player can chose to grow, there is also animals to raise, different characters to meet (and date if so inclined), items to collect, a museum to fill with interesting items, a mine with monsters to delve and fight, fishing, and a mystery surrounding the town. As the player explores and choses any given activity to develop, skill points are gained to improve specific actions.

The game is divided into seasons, and there are different weather conditions that change how some activities are played. Special events also occur in some specific moments of the game following the internal calendar.

The game can be controlled with keyboard and mouse or controller, with customizations of keys. There are also plenty of options to make the experience more comfortable, like autorun and audio options.

Updated over the years, and adding a bigger crew to the game, it‚Äôs a very polished experience with great pixel art graphics and great soundtrack.

Considering the many ways this game can be played, mostly all very relaxing, I highly recommend Stardew Valley.

Stardew Valley is an outstanding indie farming simulation game that has captivated millions of players since its release. Created by a single developer, ConcernedApe, the game offers a charming and nostalgic pixel-art style combined with deep and rewarding gameplay. Inspired by classics like Harvest Moon, Stardew Valley expands on the genre by giving players an incredible amount of freedom to shape their own farming experience.

At its core, the game revolves around revitalizing a neglected farm inherited from the player's grandfather. However, farming is just one aspect of the game. Players can grow crops, raise animals, mine for resources, fish, craft items, and even engage in combat while exploring dangerous caves. The variety of activities ensures that the game never feels repetitive, and there is always something new to discover.

One of Stardew Valley‚Äôs greatest strengths is its sense of community. The town of Pelican Town is filled with unique and lovable characters, each with their own personalities, backstories, and daily routines. Players can befriend the townspeople, learn about their lives, and even develop romantic relationships, leading to marriage and family life. This social aspect adds emotional depth to the game and makes the world feel truly alive.

The game‚Äôs open-ended nature allows players to progress at their own pace, creating a relaxing and stress-free experience. There‚Äôs no right or wrong way to play‚Äîwhether you focus on running a highly profitable farm, completing the Community Center tasks, or simply enjoying the beautiful countryside, Stardew Valley accommodates all playstyles.

Another major highlight is the multiplayer mode, which lets friends work together to build and manage a farm. This cooperative element enhances the experience, making it even more enjoyable for those who love playing with others.

With its charming art style, captivating soundtrack, and nearly endless gameplay possibilities, Stardew Valley stands out as one of the best indie games ever made. Whether you're a fan of farming simulations, RPGs, or simply looking for a cozy and immersive escape, this game is a must-play.

Stardew Valley is a great alternative for those tired of classic action games. If you're looking for a relaxing and sweet game, this one is perfect for you. Here are some tips I've learned about the game:

General Advice
Don't Cut the Grass: Before getting into livestock farming, don't cut the grass because it can be used as hay once you've built a silo. One piece of hay is worth 50g.

Watch TV: Watch your TV every day. On Sundays, you can learn new recipes from the cooking show. Some days there might be programs that give you useful information about the game.

Animals
Chicken: Once grown, it lays eggs every day. After a while, it might start giving large eggs.

Duck: Once grown, it lays eggs or feathers every other day.

Rabbit: Gives wool every 4 days.

Cow: Once grown, it produces milk every day. After a while, it might start giving large milk.

Goat: Once grown, it produces goat milk every other day. After a while, it might start giving large goat milk.

Sheep: Gives wool every 4 days.

Pig: Collects truffles. If you leave them outside every day, they will find at least 1 truffle (sometimes 2). They are useless in winter or on rainy days because animals don‚Äôt leave the barn.

Void Chicken: You can obtain it by incubating an egg you buy from Krobus in the sewer. Lays eggs every day.

Dinosaur: You can find an egg in the mines at a certain level in the desert. By placing this egg in the incubator in your coop, you can get a pet dinosaur.

Slime: Not very useful, so I don't recommend having them.

Golden Chicken and Ostrich: These are new animals added with the 1.5 update.

Mining
Luck: Before going mining, check the fortune teller on your TV to see your luck for the day.

Health Elixir: Before heading to the mines, prepare health elixirs using mushrooms.

Energy Replenishment: When tired, you can go to the spa, which opens after the earthquake, to replenish your energy.

Desert Mine: After completing the vault room in the community center, the bus service is restored, allowing you to go to the mines in the desert.

Fishing
Fishing Rod: You can start fishing by buying a rod from the fisherman at the beach. The fishing mechanic is quite simple.

Fish Species: Some fish only appear during certain seasons, in specific locations, and at specific times. For details, you can check the game‚Äôs wiki page.

Farming
Seasonal Crops: You can grow different crops each season. However, crops will wither at the end of the season, so be mindful when buying seeds.

Repairing the Greenhouse: You can repair the greenhouse by completing the tasks at the community center. In the greenhouse, crops won't wither, and you can plant anytime.

Social Relationships
Relationships: You can find out what gifts each character likes by checking the wiki page. Once you have an 8-heart relationship with a character, you can give them a bouquet to start dating. To get married, you can buy a pendant from the old mariner on rainy days.

Community Center
Tasks: By completing tasks at the community center, you can earn useful rewards.

Skills and Levels
Skills: You can improve your farming, fishing, mining, foraging, and combat skills. At levels 5 and 10, you can choose special skills.

Trait Changing: After donating to the library, you‚Äôll receive a key that opens the sewer, where you can change your traits at a statue.

Stardew Valley. It's the game that asks the profound question: "What if your crippling office job was replaced by the gentle tyranny of farming?" You inherit your grandpa's old plot of land in a place called Pelican Town, and suddenly you're thrust into a world of parsnips, pixelated perfection, and the nagging suspicion that everyone in town is way more socially adjusted than you are.

Let's talk about that pixel art. It's like someone took all the good parts of a classic SNES game and sprinkled them with fairy dust. Every blade of grass, every adorable little chicken, every suspiciously cheerful villager is rendered in glorious, vibrant detail. You almost want to reach into the screen and feel the digital dirt between your fingers.

And the atmosphere? Cozy doesn't even begin to cover it. Stardew Valley is like being wrapped in a warm, pixelated blanket. The music is soothing, the days are structured yet relaxed, and there's a constant sense of gentle progress. You start with a few seeds and a rusty hoe, and before you know it, you're running a thriving agricultural empire, befriending (and maybe marrying) the locals, and delving into mysterious mines.

You'll spend your days farming, fishing, foraging, and fighting the occasional grumpy radish. You'll become a master of resource management, juggling crops, livestock, and the ever-present need to upgrade your tools. You'll attend town festivals, where you can show off your prize-winning pumpkin or engage in some light-hearted flirting. You might even uncover ancient secrets or battle the forces of corporate evil (because even paradise has its problems).

But the best part? There's no pressure. You can play at your own pace, whether that means min-maxing your farm for maximum profit or spending the entire day chasing butterflies and trying to catch that one elusive legendary fish. Stardew Valley is a game about finding your own slice of happiness, one pixelated turnip at a time.
